{{Infobox journal | title = Konsthistorisk tidskrif
Journal of Art History | cover = | caption = | former_name = | abbreviation = Konsthistorisk Tidskr. | discipline = Art history | peer-reviewed = | language = | editor = Dan Kartholm | publisher = [[Routledge]] for Konsthistoriska sällskapet (the Society of Art Historians) | country = | history = 1932 to present | frequency = Quarterly | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | ISSNlabel = | ISSN = 0023-3609 | eISSN = 1651-2294 | CODEN = | JSTOR = | LCCN = | OCLC =46849244 | website = http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/skon20/current#.VRcIsuGxWDg | link1 = | link1-name = | link2 = | link2-name = | boxwidth = }} '''''Konsthistorisk tidskrift''''' is a quarterly [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[academic journal]] on [[art history]] that was established in 1932 by ''Konsthistoriska sällskapet'' (the Society of Art Historians) in [[Stockholm]]. The journal was published until 1967 under the full title ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift: revy för konst och konstforskning''. Since 2002 it has carried the English alternate title ''Journal of Art History''. It was published by the [[Scandinavian University Press]] from 1992 till 1999, and has been published by [[Routledge]] ([[Taylor & Francis Group]]) since 2000.[http://libris.kb.se/bib/3417286?vw=full LIBRIS entry for the ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift''] ==History== ''Konsthistoriska sällskapet'', the Society of Art Historians, was founded in 1914 on the initiative of [[Osvald Sirén]], J. A. Berg Professor of Art History in Stockholm, and [[Johnny Roosval]], then docent of Art History (later professor). The society was clearly Stockholm-centric from the start: Sirén and Roosval became chairman and vice chairman, respectively. The rest of the board consisted of representatives of the major museums in Stockholm, the director of the [[Bukowskis]] auction house there, and the other universities in Lund, Uppsala and Gothenburg each having one representative ([[Ewert Wrangel]], [[August Hahr]] and [[Axel Romdahl]], respectively).Pettersson (2000), p. 85-86 ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift'' had a predecessor in the first periodical of the society, ''Konsthistoriska sällskapets publikation'', which was published 1915-1925.[http://libris.kb.se/bib/420689?vw=full LIBRIS entry for the ''Konsthistoriska Sällskapets Publikation''] From 1926, it was absorbed into the journal ''[[Tidskrift för konstvetenskap]]'', which had been published at the [[University of Lund]] since 1916.[http://libris.kb.se/bib/420689?vw=full LIBRIS], [http://libris.kb.se/bib/408986?vw=full LIBRIS]; Ångström-Grandien (2001) At the annual meeting of Konsthistoriska sällskapet in 1931, the board of the Society proposed re-establishing a periodical of its own, as {{blockquote|despite the merits of [Tidskrift för konstvetenskap], it has become apparent that it would be more suitable for the publication of the Society to be edited from Stockholm, as most art historical authors and most members live here, and it must, additionally, be easier to satisfy the interests of art history and the art collectors in all parts of the country with Stockholm as the base.Sjöblom (1932), p. 123-124. Sjöberg's Swedish summary of the prospect presented by the board: "Sällskapets publikation har under senare åren utgjorts av den i Lund utgivna och redigerade Tidskrift för Konstvetenskap. Trots denna tidskrifts förtjänster har det dock visat sig vara mera lämpligt, att Sällskapets publikation redigeras från Stockholm, då de flesta konsthistoriska författarna och de flesta ledamöterna äro bosatta här, och det dessutom måste falla sig lättare att med Stockholm som utgångspunkt allsidigt tillgodose konstvetenskapens och konstsamlarnas intressen i alla delar av vårt land. Styrelsen har därför planerat en Konsthistorisk Tidskrift av ungefär samma format och omfång som den förutvarande Publikationen. Den nya tidskriften kommer att gratis tillsändas ledamöterna, och årsavgiften för ledamotskap förblir oförändrad."}} The journal was to be of approximately the same size as the previous publication and would be distributed to members with no change in fees. After a short debate, the meeting agreed to the proposition of the board. Professor Axel Romdahl from Gothenburg suggested a division of the field between the two journals in some way and offered to negotiate this with representatives of the other journal.Sjöblom (1932), p. 124 The 1960-1984 annual volumes of the journal included "Svensk konsthistorisk bibliografi" (from 1976 known as "konstvetenskaplig bibliografi"), an annual cumulative bibliography of art history published in Sweden, covering the years 1959-1985.[http://libris.kb.se/bib/3417286?vw=full LIBRIS] ==Editors== The journal originally had an editorial group consisting of an ''ansvarig utgivare'' ("publisher", the person responsible for the publication under ''Tryckfrihetsförordningen'', the Swedish [[Constitution of Sweden#Freedom of the press and freedom of expression|Freedom of the Press Act]]) and one or several ''redaktör[er]'' ("editor[s]").[http://libris.kb.se/bib/3417286?vw=full LIBRIS] The position of ''ansvarig utgivare'' ("publisher") for the journal has been held by: *[[Johnny Roosval]] (1932-1965:1/2) *Sten Karling (1965:3/4–1973) *Patrik Reuterswärd (1974–1990) *Hans Henrik Brummer (1991) The position of ''redaktör'', ("editor") for the journal has been held by: *Georg Svensson (1932–1944) *Kjell Boström, Aron Andersson, [[Axel Boëthius]] and Georg Svensson (1945) *Kjell Boström, Aron Andersson and Georg Svensson (1946:1-2) *Johnny Roosval (1947) *Sten Karling (1948–1973) *Lars Olof Larsson and Ingrid Sjöström (1974–1980) *Götz Pochat and Patrik Reuterswärd (1981:1) *Patrik Reuterswärd (1981:2–1990) Since 1992 the person responsible for the journal has been described by the English title "Editor-in-chief" and has been: *Hans Henrik Brummer (1992–2001) *Margaretha Rossholm Lagerlöf (2002–2009?) *The current [[editor in chief]] is Dan Kartholm.[http://www.tandf.co.uk/journals/journal.asp?issn=0023-3609&linktype=5 ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift'', Editorial Board] In addition, the journal has and has had a larger advisory committee. The first issue from 1932 listed one consisting of 27 people. ==Recognition== The journal is financially supported by the [[Swedish Research Council]].The on-line database shows it receiving 120,000 [[Swedish krona|SEK]] annually for 2002–2008: [http://vrproj.vr.se/detail.asp?arendeid=5493 2002], [http://vrproj.vr.se/detail.asp?arendeid=14449 2003], [http://vrproj.vr.se/detail.asp?arendeid=22511 2004], [http://vrproj.vr.se/detail.asp?arendeid=30995 2005, 2006, 2007], [http://vrproj.vr.se/detail.asp?arendeid=56525 2008]. The [[European Reference Index for the Humanities]] classifies ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift'' as a category "A" journal in the field of Art, Architectural and Design History (2008).European Science Foundation: [http://www.esf.org/index.php?eID=tx_nawsecuredl&u=0&file=fileadmin/be_user/research_areas/HUM/Documents/ERIH/Initial_Lists/AADHFINAL.pdf&t=1233437507&hash=8a3b4542751a80cd76918b28abb7ec38 ERIH Initial List: Art, Architectural and Design History (2008)] It is also included in the American [[Arts & Humanities Citation Index]],[http://science.thomsonreuters.com/cgi-bin/jrnlst/jlresults.cgi?PC=H&Word=konsthistorisk%20tidskrift Search for "Konsthistorisk tidskrift" in the A&HCI] and an American librarian has described it as "a major Scandinavian art history journal that is highly regarded in the United States".de Luise (2002), p. 119 ==Notes== {{reflist|2}} ==References== ===Databases=== *[http://libris.kb.se/ LIBRIS (the joint catalogue of the Swedish academic and research libraries)] *[http://vrproj.vr.se Vetenskapsrådets projektdatabas] (the project database of the [[Swedish Research Council]]). *[http://science.thomsonreuters.com/cgi-bin/jrnlst/jloptions.cgi?PC=H Arts & Humanities Citation Index, journal database] ===Publications and reports=== *Ångström-Grandien, Inga Lena: "[http://www.informaworld.com/index/MFKHQDQBP3DWNBAV.pdf Tidskrift för konstvetenskap, ett forum för konstforskning]", ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift'', 70:1-2 (June 2001), pp. 77–87. *[[European Science Foundation]], Standing Committee for the Humanities: "[http://www.esf.org/index.php?eID=tx_nawsecuredl&u=0&file=fileadmin/be_user/research_areas/HUM/Documents/ERIH/Initial_Lists/AADHFINAL.pdf&t=1233437507&hash=8a3b4542751a80cd76918b28abb7ec38 ERIH Initial List: Art, Architectural and Design History (2008)]" *de Luise, Alexandra: "[https://books.google.com/books?id=O-1qrN9FlYoC&pg=PA118&dq=konsthistorisk+tidskrift&lr= Journals of the Century in the Visual Arts]" [ch. 7], in: Tony Stankus (ed.): ''Journals of the Century'', New York: Haworth Information Press, 2002, p. 115 ff (chapter orig. publ. in ''[[The Serials Librarian]]'' 39(4):79-102, 2001.) *Pettersson, Hans: "Konsthistoria som universitetsdisciplin", in: Britt-Inger Johansson & Hans Pettersson (eds.), ''8 kapitel om konsthistoriens historia i Sverige'', Stockholm: Rasters förlag, 2000, p. 63-91. *Sjöblom, Axel: "Kort redogörelse för Konsthistoriska Sällskapets verksamhet okt. 1931-maj 1932", ''Konsthistorisk tidskrift'' 1 (1932), p. 123-124. ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.tandf.co.uk/journals/titles/00233609.asp}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Konsthistorisk Tidskrift}} [[Category:Art history journals]] [[Category:Multilingual journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1932]] [[Category:Routledge academic journals]]

This is a '''list of nutrition guides'''. A nutrition guide is a [[reference]] that provides [[nutrition]] advice for general [[health]], typically by dividing foods into [[food group]]s and recommending [[serving size|servings]] of each group. Nutrition guides can be presented in written or visual form, and are commonly published by [[government agency|government agencies]], [[health association]]s and [[university]] health [[academic department|departments]].
Most countries also have [[nutrition facts label]]s which are not listed here; many of those reference specific target amounts for various nutrients.
==Historical guides==
===Ancient Greece=== The [[Hippocratic Corpus]] of [[Ancient Greece]] contains one of the earliest known nutrition guides. It recommends a [[season]]al [[diet (nutrition)|diet]]. For [[winter]], it advises eating a heavy diet of bread and roasted meat and fish, while avoiding vegetables and restricting liquids to, if anything, strong wine. It then recommends a lighter [[summer]] diet of soft [[barley]] cake, vegetables, boiled meat, and large quantities of diluted wine. Gradual transitions between these two diets are advised in the intervening months.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hippocratic Writings|year=1983|publisher=Penguin|isbn=978-0-14-044451-3|pages=272–273|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KKjpaVEpP9oC|author=Various|editor1=G. E. R. Lloyd |editor2=J. Chadwick |editor3=W. N. Mann |accessdate=6 June 2011|chapter=A Regimen for Health}}</ref>
===Imperial China=== During the [[Tang Dynasty]], [[China|Chinese]] [[physician]] [[Sun Simiao]] is believed to have written the first nutrition guide in [[traditional Chinese medicine]]. In his book, ''Precious Prescriptions for Emergencies'' ({{zh|c=[[wikt:備|備]][[wikt:急|急]][[wikt:千|千]][[wikt:金|金]][[wikt:要|要]][[wikt:方|方]]|p=Beiji qianjin yaofang}}), the chapter "Dietary Treatment" ({{zh|c=[[wikt:食|食]][[wikt:治|治]]|p=Shiji}}) contains sections describing the effects of eating fruits, vegetables, grains and animals.<ref>{{cite book|last=Hsu|first=Elisabeth|title=Innovation in Chinese Medicine|year=2001|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=0-521-80068-4|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BbYYstLfSyUC|accessdate=6 June 2011|chapter=Dietetics in Tang China and the first extant works of ''materia diatetica''|page=176}}</ref>
===First food pyramid=== Amid high food prices in 1972, [[Sweden]]'s [[National Board of Health and Welfare (Sweden)|National Board of Health and Welfare]] developed the idea of "basic foods" that were both cheap and [[nutritious]], and "supplemental foods" that added nutrition missing from the basic foods. [[Kooperativa Förbundet|KF]], a [[cooperative federation|consumer co-op]] that worked with the Board, sought to illustrate these food groups. KF developed a [[food guide pyramid|food pyramid]] because it could depict basic foods as its base, and introduced the guide to the public in 1974 in their magazine, ''[[:sv:Vi (tidning)|Vi]]''. At the base were bread, cereals, potatoes, milk, cheese and margarine; above it was a large section of supplemental [[vegetables]] and [[fruit]]; and at the top was an apex of supplemental meat, fish and eggs. The pyramid competed with the National Board's "dietary circle," which KF saw as problematic for resembling a cake divided into seven slices, and for not indicating how much of each food should be eaten. While the Board distanced itself from the pyramid, KF continued to promote it, and food pyramids were developed in other [[Scandinavia]]n countries, plus [[West Germany]], [[Japan]] and [[Sri Lanka]]. The United States later developed its first food pyramid in 1992.<ref name=KFPyramid>{{cite web|url=http://www.mersmak.kf.se/Toppmeny-startsida-/KFBibliotek/Kooperativ-kronika-startsida/Sok/KF-Kronika---Visa-artikel/?articleid=641 |title=Ett provkok blev provkök |language=Swedish |date=2008-10-03 |work=KF |accessdate=2011-01-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120325031502/http://www.mersmak.kf.se/Toppmeny-startsida-/KFBibliotek/Kooperativ-kronika-startsida/Sok/KF-Kronika---Visa-artikel/?articleid=641 |archivedate=2012-03-25 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.coop.se/Globala-sidor/OmKF/Kooperativ-samverkan/Var-historia1/Tidslinjen/1960-19901/1973/KF-Provkok-lanserar-iden-om-basmat/ |title=KF Provkök lanserar idén om basmat |language=Swedish |year=1973 |work=Coop |publisher=KF |accessdate=2011-01-22 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110929023533/http://www.coop.se/Globala-sidor/OmKF/Kooperativ-samverkan/Var-historia1/Tidslinjen/1960-19901/1973/KF-Provkok-lanserar-iden-om-basmat/ |archivedate=2011-09-29 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=matpyramid|url=http://www.ne.se/matpyramid|work=Nationalencyklopedin|accessdate=7 June 2011|language=Swedish}}</ref>
Today, both the Swedish government and KF have moved to the [[#Sweden|Plate Model]].<ref name=LVPlate>{{cite web|title=Tallriksmodellen|url=http://www.slv.se/sv/grupp1/Mat-och-naring/Matcirkeln-och-tallriksmoddellen/Tallriksmodellen/|work=Livsmedelsverket|accessdate=9 June 2011|language=Swedish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110612103654/http://www.slv.se/sv/grupp1/Mat-och-naring/Matcirkeln-och-tallriksmoddellen/Tallriksmodellen/|archivedate=12 June 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Sunda Bröd & Smörgåsar|url=http://www.mersmak.kf.se/upload/KF%20Konsument/sunda-brod.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061005175837/http://www.mersmak.kf.se/upload/KF%20Konsument/sunda-brod.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 October 2006|work=KF|accessdate=9 June 2011|language=Swedish|format=PDF}}</ref>
==Government guides==
===Australia=== The [[Australia]]n [[Department of Health and Ageing]] publishes '''''The Australian Guide to Healthy Eating''''', which features a wheel divided into five sections: approximately 40 percent bread, cereals, rice, pasta and noodles; 30 percent vegetables and legumes; 10 percent fruit; 10 percent milk, yogurt and cheese; and 10 percent lean meat, fish, poultry, eggs, nuts and legumes. Below the wheel are reminders to drink plenty of water and eat fats and sweets occasionally or in small amounts.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Australian Guide to Healthy Eating – Enjoy a Variety of Foods Every Day|url=http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/content/health-pubhlth-strateg-food-guide-guide2.htm|work=Australian Government Department of Health and Ageing|accessdate=3 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319033600/http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/Content/health-pubhlth-strateg-food-guide-guide2.htm|archivedate=19 March 2011|df=}}</ref> More specific recommendations are provided based on age, gender, life stage and activity level.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Australian Guide to Healthy Eating: Background information for consumers|url=http://www.health.gov.au/internet/main/publishing.nsf/content/E384CFA588B74377CA256F190004059B/$File/fd-cons.pdf|work=Australian Department of Health and Ageing|accessdate=6 June 2011|format=PDF}}</ref>
===Austria=== The [[Austria]]n Federal Ministry of Health uses '''The Austrian Food Pyramid''' ({{lang-de|Die Österreichische Ernährungspyramide}}), which is divided into 25 blocks, each block representing a daily serving from a food group. Starting at the base, there are six servings of non-alcoholic beverages (preferably low-energy drinks like water, tea, unsweetened fruit juice and vegetable juice); three servings of vegetables and legumes; two of fruit; four of cereals, bread, pasta, rice and potatoes (preferably whole grains); three of milk and dairy (two "white," like milk, yogurt or cream cheese, and one of yellow cheese); one of fats and oil (preferably olive or canola oil); three of meat, fish, sausage and eggs (preferably fish or lean meat); and three of fatty, sweet and salty foods (though not nutritionally recommended and to be consumed rarely).<ref>{{cite web|title=Die Österreichische Ernährungspyramide|url=http://www.bmg.gv.at/home/Schwerpunkte/Ernaehrung/Empfehlungen/DIE_OeSTERREICHISCHE_ERNAeHRUNGSPYRAMIDE|work=Bundesministerium für Gesundheit|accessdate=12 June 2011|language=German}}</ref>
===Belgium=== The Voedingsdriehoek is a (mostly in Flanders) widely used tool for dietitians, health educators, schools, etc. to explain a balanced diet. The triangle is constructed as a pyramid with five different layers. The bottom layer is the largest in area, so the most important, the top is narrow and there represents little food, although it is an essential ingredient. The layers are (from top to bottom): - Oil / fats - Protein: meat, fish, eggs, dairy products, meat substitutes - Fruits and vegetables - Starch or carbohydrates (bread, potatoes, rice, pasta, etc.) - Drinks In 2005 a (rather symbolically) layer was added at the bottom: sports and exercise. This is not a food, but an important part of a healthy diet and lifestyle. The information services use the "active" food pyramid.
===Brazil=== [[Brazil]]'s [[Ministry of Health (Brazil)|Ministry of Health]] publishes the '''''Food Guide''''' ({{lang-pt|Guia Alimentar}}), which features a map of Brazil depicting each of [[Regions of Brazil|Brazil's five regions]] as puzzle pieces representing a food group. However, Brazil's food recommendations differ from the map, and feature eight food groups: rice, bread, pasta, potato and cassavas (5 servings a day); vegetables and legumes (3 servings); fruits (3); milk, cheese and yogurt (3); beans (1); meat, fish and eggs (1); oils and fats (1); and sugars and sweets (no more than one).<ref>{{cite web|title=Guia Alimentar|url=http://dab.saude.gov.br/portaldab/biblioteca.php?conteudo=publicacoes/guia_alimentar2014|work=Ministério da Saúde|language=Portuguese|format=PDF}}</ref>
===Canada=== {{main|Canada's Food Guide}} '''''[[Canada's Food Guide]]''''' from [[Health Canada]] is illustrated with a [[rainbow]] of four food groups: vegetables and fruit (7 to 10 servings a day for adults, depending on biological sex), grain products (6 to 8), milk and alternatives (2), and meat and alternatives (2 to 3).<ref>{{cite web|title=Eating Well with Canada's Food Guide|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fn-an/food-guide-aliment/index-eng.php|work=Health Canada|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> More specific recommendations are provided based on age, gender and life stage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eating Well with Canada's Food Guide – A Resource for Educators and Communicators|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fn-an/pubs/res-educat/res-educat-eng.php|work=Health Canada|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref>
Canada developed its first nutrition guide in 1942 as part of its [[World War II|wartime]] nutrition program.<ref>{{cite web|title=Canada's Food Guides from 1942 to 1992|url=http://www.hc-sc.gc.ca/fn-an/food-guide-aliment/context/fg_history-histoire_ga-eng.php|work=Health Canada|accessdate=6 June 2011}}</ref>
===China=== [[China]]'s [[Ministry of Health of the People's Republic of China|Ministry of Health]] uses the '''Balanced Diet [[Pagoda]]''' ({{zh|[[wikt:平|平]][[wikt:衡|衡]][[wikt:膳|膳]][[wikt:食|食]][[wikt:宝|宝]][[wikt:塔|塔]]}}), which is divided into five [[storey|stories]] ascending from largest to smallest. Cereals are at the large base; topped by vegetables and fruits; then fish, poultry, meat, eggs and other animal foods; followed by milk and soy foods; and topped with fats and oils in the small [[spire]]. Beside the pagoda are images representing water and exercise.<ref>{{cite web|title=Ministry of Health issued "China's Dietary Guidelines (2007)"|url=http://www.gov.cn/xwfb/2008-01/15/content_858517.htm|work=The Central People's Government of the People's Republic of China|accessdate=3 June 2011|language=Chinese}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Dietary Guidelines for Chinese Residents|url=http://www.lxzfda.gov.cn/news_view.asp?news_id=126869|work=LinXia Food and Drug Administration|accessdate=3 June 2011|language=Chinese|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324232342/http://www.lxzfda.gov.cn/news_view.asp?news_id=126869|archivedate=24 March 2012|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Nutrition Dietary Pagoda|url=http://www.scmiyi.gov.cn/smpd/shjk/ysbd/12990.shtml|archive-url=https://archive.is/20120805193525/http://www.scmiyi.gov.cn/smpd/shjk/ysbd/12990.shtml|dead-url=yes|archive-date=5 August 2012|work=Public information network of MIYI county|accessdate=3 June 2011|language=Chinese}}</ref>
===Denmark=== [[Denmark]]'s Food Administration uses the '''Diet Compass''' ({{lang-da|Kostkompasset}}) to depict its "Dietary 8" ({{lang-da|8 kostråd}}) guidelines, with an image on each compass point representing a guideline. Those guidelines are: "Eat 6 fruits and vegetables a day," "Eat fish and seafood several times a week," "Eat potatoes, rice or pasta and whole wheat bread every day," "Cut back on sugar," "Cut back on greasy foods," "Eat a varied diet and maintain a normal weight," "Quench your thirst with water," and, "Be physically active at least 30 minutes a day."<ref>{{cite web|title=Kostkompasset|url=http://www.altomkost.dk/Services/Materialer_og_undervisning/Kostkompasset/forside.htm|work=Fødevarestyrelsen|accessdate=12 June 2011|language=Danish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110903205510/http://www.altomkost.dk/Services/Materialer_og_undervisning/Kostkompasset/forside.htm|archivedate=3 September 2011|df=}}</ref>
===France=== [[France]]'s [[:fr:Institut national de prévention et d'éducation pour la santé|National Institute for Prevention and Health Education]] has 25 separate food guides under the title '''The Food Guide For All''' ({{lang-fr|Le Guide Alimentaire Pour Tous}}). Each guide is based on a consumer's personality, habits and lifestyle. There are guides for people who: are health-conscious, don't care about food, prepare family meals, are poor, eat at restaurants, skip meals, don't cook, have large appetites, are on diets, prefer certain foods, avoid various foods (including meat), are sedentary, are athletic, and more. Each guide features a "portrait" in the image of a happy face designed out of foods representing that consumer's type. The portraits are billed as nutrition recommendations, though they are more decorative than informative.<ref>{{cite web|title=Le guide alimentaire pour tous|url=http://www.inpes.sante.fr/espace_nutrition/guide/presentation/mode.asp|work=Institut national de prévention et d'éducation pour la santé|accessdate=3 June 2011|language=French}}</ref>
===Germany=== [[Germany]]'s state-funded [[:de:Aid infodienst|Aid Information Service]] uses the '''Food Pyramid''' ({{lang-de|Ernährungspyramide}}), which divides a pyramid into 22 blocks, each block representing a hand-sized serving from a food group. Starting at the base, there are six blocks for beverages, three for vegetables, two for fruit, four for grains, three for dairy, one for meat and fish, one for oils, one for fats, and one for sweets and alcohol. Beverages, vegetables, fruit and grains are marked green for "free travel"; meat and dairy are marked yellow for "caution"; and oils, fats, sweets and alcohol are marked red for "brake lights".<ref>{{cite web|title=Die aid-Ernährungspyramide|url=http://www.was-wir-essen.de/gesund/empfehlungen_aid_pyramide.php|work=was-wir-essen|publisher=aid infodienst|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=German}}</ref> Aid also collaborated with the German Nutrition Society to create a [[three-dimensional space|3D]] pyramid model.<ref>{{cite web|title=Die dreidimensionale Lebensmittelpyramide|url=http://www.dge.de/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=481|work=Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ernährung|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=German}}</ref>
===India=== [[India]]'s [[National Institute of Nutrition, Hyderabad|National Institute of Nutrition]] publishes the '''''Dietary Guidelines for Indians''''', which, among other diagrams, includes the Food Pyramid. The pyramid has a base of beans and legumes to eat adequately, a second layer of vegetables and fruit to eat liberally, a third layer of meat, fish, eggs and oils to eat moderately, and an apex of fatty, salty and sugary foods to eat sparingly. Accompanying the pyramid is a recommendation of regular exercise and physical activity, as well as warnings against drinking alcohol and smoking.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dietary Guidelines for Indians|url=http://www.ninindia.org/DietaryguidelinesforIndians-Finaldraft.pdf|work=National Institute of Nutrition|accessdate=12 June 2011|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110516002639/http://www.ninindia.org/DietaryguidelinesforIndians-Finaldraft.pdf|archivedate=16 May 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Ireland=== The island of [[Ireland]]'s [[Food Safety Promotion Board]] uses '''The Food Pyramid''', which is divided into five levels: bread, cereals and potatoes at the large base (6 or more servings); then fruit and vegetables (5); followed by milk, cheese and yogurt (3); then meat, fish, eggs and alternatives (2); and finally fats, high fat/sugar snacks, foods and drinks at the apex (small amounts). At least 8 cups of water a day are also recommended.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Food Pyramid|url=http://www.safefood.eu/en/Consumer/Healthy-Living/Eating-Well/Eating-well1/The-food-pyramid/|work=safefood|publisher=The Food Safety Promotion Board|accessdate=6 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712035747/http://www.safefood.eu/en/Consumer/Healthy-Living/Eating-Well/Eating-well1/The-food-pyramid/|archivedate=12 July 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Israel=== The '''Food Pyramid''' ({{lang-he|[[:he:פירמידת המזון|פירמידת המזון]]}}) from [[Israel]]'s [[Ministry of Health (Israel)|Ministry of Health]] is divided into six levels. At the wide base is water; followed by starches, including pasta, bread, corn and yams; then fruits and vegetables; then meat, fish, eggs and dairy; then fats and oils; and finally sugary foods at the small apex. Images around the pyramid represent exercise.<ref>{{cite web|title=Food Pyramid|url=http://www.health.gov.il/pages/default.asp?maincat=33&catid=846|work=Ministry of Health|accessdate=6 June 2011|language=Hebrew}}</ref>
===Italy=== The [[Italy|Italian]] [[Ministry of Health (Italy)|Ministry of Health]] uses the '''Italian Food Pyramid''' ({{lang-it|Piramide Alimentare Italiana}}), which is divided into squares, triangles, [[trapezoid]]s and rectangles that represent one, one-half, one-and-a-half, and two servings, respectively. Beginning from the base, the divisions are: fruit (2 servings), water (1), vegetables (2), bread (1.5), biscotti (0.5), potatoes (0.5), rice and pasta (1.5), meat (1), eggs (0.5), fish (0.5), legumes (0.5), [[cold cut]] meats (0.5), milk (0.5), dairy (0.5), oils and fats (1), sweets (0.5) and wine or beer (0.5). Along the edges of the pyramid are triangles representing physical activity. The pyramid is intended to represent the variety of foods eaten over an entire week, averaged into daily portions. Also provided is an alternative, more traditional pyramid for a single day, divided into six layers representing six food groups; as well as two additional pyramids for children.<ref>{{cite web|title=Piramide Alimentare Italiana|url=http://www.piramidealimentare.it/|work=Istituto di Scienza dell'Alimentazione|publisher=Università di Roma|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=Italian}}</ref>
===Japan=== The '''Food Guide''' ({{lang-ja|食事バランスガイド}}), from [[Japan]]'s [[Ministry of Health, Labour and Welfare (Japan)|Health]] and [[Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries (Japan)|Agriculture]] ministries, is depicted as a [[top|spinning top]] with a wide upper layer tapering to a narrow bottom. At the large upper level is a [[staple food|staple meal]] of carbohydrates, including rice, bread and noodles (5 to 7 servings a day); followed below by a [[side dish]] of vegetables, potatoes, beans (except soybeans), mushrooms and seaweed (5 to 6); then a smaller [[main course]] of protein, including meat, fish, eggs and soy (3 to 5); and finally the narrow point, divided between dairy (2) and fruit (2). The top's handle is filled with "essential" water and tea, and running in circles around the handle is a figure representing moderate exercise. A small [[motion lines|motion line]] beside the top represents sweet beverages in moderation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Food Guide|url=http://www.maff.go.jp/j/balance_guide/|work=Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries|accessdate=3 June 2011|language=Japanese}}</ref>
===Mexico=== [[Mexico]]'s Department of Nutrition and Health Promotion uses '''The Plate of Good Eating''' ({{lang-es|El Plato del Bien Comer}}), which is divided into thirds: vegetables and fruits (in equal proportion); cereals; and legumes and animal products. The guide further recommends eating "many" vegetables and fruits and "enough" cereals. The legume and animal products section is subdivided, and "few" animal products are recommended, while the guide recommends combining the larger legume section with cereals. Additional recommendations are to include each of the three food groups in each of the three main meals of the day, to eat the greatest possible variety of food, to eat according to individual needs and conditions, and to eat the least possible fats, oils, sugar and salt.<ref>{{cite web|title=El Plato del Bien Comer|url=http://www.fns.org.mx/index.php?IdContenido=46|work=Fomento de Nutrición y Salud|language=Spanish}}</ref>
===Netherlands=== The [[Netherlands]] Nutrition Center uses the '''Wheel of Five''' ({{lang-nl|[[:nl:Schijf van vijf|De Schijf van Vijf]]}}), which is divided into five groups: approximately 30 percent vegetables and fruit; 30 percent bread, cereals, potatoes, rice, pasta, couscous, and legumes; 16 percent dairy, meat, fish, eggs and meat substitutes; 16 percent beverages; and 8 percent fats and oils. More specific recommendations are provided based on age and gender.<ref>{{cite web|title=De Schijf van Vijf|url=http://www.voedingscentrum.nl/nl/schijf-van-vijf/schijf.aspx|work=Het Voedingscentrum|accessdate=4 June 2011|language=Dutch}}</ref>
===South Korea=== [[South Korea]]'s Korean Nutrition Society uses the '''Food Bicycle''' ({{lang-ko|식품구성 자전거}}), with a small front wheel filled with water and a large rear wheel composed of approximately one-third grains; 20 percent meat, fish, eggs and beans; 20 percent vegetables; 12 percent fruits; 12 percent dairy; and 3 percent oils and sugars. A person is pedaling the bicycle, representing exercise. More specific recommendations are provided based on age, gender and life stage.<ref>{{cite web|title=Dietary Reference Intakes for Koreans 2010|url=http://image.campushomepage.com/users/knsweb/ssugi513/DRIs/2010KDRIs_open_final.pdf|work=The Korean Nutrition Society|accessdate=6 June 2011|language=Korean|format=PDF}}</ref>
Before 2010, South Korea used a [[:ko:파일:Korean food pyramid.jpg|food pagoda model]] very similar to China's current guide.<ref>{{cite web|title=List of dietary reference intake publilcations|url=http://www.kns.or.kr/board.asp?catalogid=kns2008&language=en&boardcode=sub07_01|work=The Korean Nutrition Society|accessdate=4 June 2011|location=Select first item dated 2007.04.11 (direct link does not work)|language=English, Korean|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120324235113/http://www.kns.or.kr/board.asp?catalogid=kns2008&language=en&boardcode=sub07_01|archivedate=24 March 2012|df=}}</ref>
===Spain=== [[Spain]]'s Ministry of Health, Social Policy and Equality uses the '''NAOS Pyramid''' ({{lang-es|Pirámide NAOS}}), which promotes a [[Mediterranean diet]] as well as plenty of physical activity, and is drawn as a sailboat on water. It is divided into beverages and water at the base; an equal division between physical activity and a combination of grains, vegetables, tubers, fruit, olive oil and dairy in the second level, which is labeled "several times a day" and color-coded green; an equal division between sports and a combination of meat, fish, eggs, legumes and nuts in the third level, which is labeled "several times a week" and is color-coded orange; and an apex of saturated fats, sugars, salt, and sedentary activity labeled "occasionally" and color-coded red.<ref>{{cite web|title=Pirámide NAOS|url=http://www.naos.aesan.mspsi.es/csym/piramide/|work=Ministerio de Sanidad, Política Social e Igualdad|publisher=Gobierno de España|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=Spanish|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110301064250/http://www.naos.aesan.mspsi.es/csym/piramide/|archivedate=1 March 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Sweden=== [[Sweden]]'s Food Agency uses the '''Plate Model''' ({{lang-sv|Tallriksmodellen}}), which divides a plate into approximately 40 percent potatoes, rice, pasta and bread; 40 percent vegetables and fruit; and 20 percent meat, fish, eggs and legumes. People requiring more energy are allowed a larger share of carbohydrates, while people who are overweight can make up to half their plate vegetables and fruit.<ref name=LVPlate/>
Previously, Sweden used the Dietary Circle created in 1963, while Swedish consumer cooperative KF created the world's first food pyramid in 1974.<ref name=KFPyramid/>
===Switzerland=== [[Switzerland]]'s Federal Office of Public Health uses the '''Food Pyramid''' ({{lang-de|Lebensmittelpyramide}}) developed by the Swiss Society for Nutrition. At the base is 1 to 2 liters of liquids, preferably non-sugared beverages; then three servings of vegetables and two servings of fruit of different colors; followed by whole grains, beans, cereals and potatoes to be eaten with each meal; then three servings of milk or dairy; one serving of meat, fish, eggs, cheese or another protein; oils, fats and nuts daily in moderation; and an apex of sweet/salty snacks and sweetened/alcoholic drinks in moderation for pleasure.<ref>{{cite web|title=Recommendations for healthy, tasty eating and drinking for adults|url=http://www.sge-ssn.ch/fileadmin/pdf/100-ernaehrungsthemen/10-gesundes_essen_trinken/Food_Pyramid.pdf|work=Swiss Society for Nutrition|accessdate=12 June 2011|format=PDF|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111102034630/http://www.sge-ssn.ch/fileadmin/pdf/100-ernaehrungsthemen/10-gesundes_essen_trinken/Food_Pyramid.pdf|archivedate=2 November 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Lebensmittelpyramide|url=http://www.bag.admin.ch/themen/ernaehrung_bewegung/05207/05214/index.html|work=Bundesamt für Gesundheit|accessdate=12 June 2011|language=German|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928200158/http://www.bag.admin.ch/themen/ernaehrung_bewegung/05207/05214/index.html|archivedate=28 September 2011|df=}}</ref>
===Turkey=== [[Turkey]]'s [[Ministry of Health (Turkey)|Ministry of Health]] uses the '''Basic Food Groups''' ({{lang-tr|Temel Besin Grupları}}), a four-part division of milk and dairy; meat, eggs, fish, legumes and seeds; vegetables and fruit; and bread and cereal. Each food group is accompanied by bullet points, such as serving recommendations or advice to eat more raw vegetables and whole grains.<ref>{{cite web|title=Temel Besin Grupları|url=http://www.beslenme.saglik.gov.tr/index.php?pid=188|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101014130125/http://www.beslenme.saglik.gov.tr/index.php?pid=188|dead-url=yes|archive-date=14 October 2010|work=Sağlık Bakanlığı|accessdate=12 June 2011|language=Turkish}}</ref>
===United Kingdom=== {{main|Eatwell plate|Dietary Reference Values}} [[File:Eatwell Plate.png|thumb|The Eatwell plate, as described by the United Kingdom's NHS and FSA.]] The [[United Kingdom]]'s Department of Health published Dietary Reference Values. These are equivalent to the easier to understand [[Eatwell plate]] used by the [[National Health Service]]. This consists of roughly one-third fruit and vegetables ("at least 5 portions"); one-third bread, rice, potatoes and pasta ("plenty"); a smaller amount of milk and dairy ("some"); meat, fish, eggs and beans in the same proportion as dairy ("some"); and a small wedge of fatty and sugary foods.<ref>{{cite web|title=The eatwell plate|url=http://www.nhs.uk/Livewell/Goodfood/Pages/eatwell-plate.aspx|work=National Health Service|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref>
===United States=== [[File:USDA MyPlate green.svg|thumb|[[MyPlate]], from the [[United States]] [[United States Department of Agriculture|Department of Agriculture]]]] {{main|MyPlate|History of USDA nutrition guides}} In the [[United States]], the [[United States Department of Agriculture|Department of Agriculture]] uses '''[[MyPlate]]''', a plate icon divided into approximately 30 percent grains, 30 percent vegetables, 20 percent fruits and 20 percent protein, accompanied by a smaller circle representing dairy. Additional recommendations include to enjoy food but eat less, avoid oversized portions, make at least half of grains [[whole grain|whole]], switch to fat-free or low-fat milk, choose foods with less sodium, and drink water instead of sugary drinks.
Previous USDA food guides include the [[History of USDA nutrition guides#Basic 7|Basic 7]] (1943–1956), the [[History of USDA nutrition guides#Basic Four|Basic Four]] (1956–1992), the [[Food Guide Pyramid]] (1992–2005), and [[MyPyramid]] (2005–2011).
The [[National Institutes of Health]] uses the Dietary Approaches to Stop [[Hypertension]] ('''DASH''') '''Eating Plan''' for people seeking to lower their [[blood pressure]]. DASH differs from MyPlate in that the protein category is replaced by a smaller proportion of lean meats, [[poultry]], and [[fish (food)|fish]]; there are separate sections for fats and [[vegetable fats and oils|oils]], legumes, and [[confectionery|sweets]]; and fruits and vegetables don't constitute half of the diet.<ref>{{cite web|title=Healthier Eating with DASH|url=http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/hbp/prevent/h_eating/h_e_dash.htm|work=National Institutes of Health|accessdate=3 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716051126/http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/hbp/prevent/h_eating/h_e_dash.htm|archivedate=16 July 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=What Is the DASH Eating Plan?|url=http://www.nhlbi.nih.gov/health/dci/Diseases/dash/dash_what.html|work=National Institutes of Health|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref>
The [[Center for Nutrition Policy and Promotion]] in the USDA and the [[United States Department of Health and Human Services]] jointly release a longer textual document called ''[[Dietary Guidelines for Americans]]'', updated in 2015 with the next scheduled revision in 2012.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cnpp.usda.gov/dietaryguidelines.htm|title=Dietary Guidelines for Americans|publisher=}}</ref>
[[Dietary Reference Intake]] values are published by the [[Institute of Medicine]] for general use, but [[nutrition facts label]]s in the U.S. use the older [[Reference Daily Intake]] standards instead.
===World Health Organization=== The [[World Health Organization]] uses '''The 3 Fives''', a guide featuring five key points in each of three categories. The three categories are safer food, a healthy diet, and appropriate physical activity. In the healthy diet category, the five keys are: "Give your baby only breast milk for the first 6 months of life," "Eat a variety of food," "Eat plenty of vegetables and fruit," "Eat moderate amounts of fats and oil," and "Eat less salt and sugar." Each key includes bullet points with further recommendations. The 3 Fives was originally developed for distribution at major sporting events like the [[Olympic Games|Olympics]] and the [[FIFA World Cup|World Cup]], but it can also be used for general audiences.<ref>{{cite web|title=The 3 Fives|url=http://www.who.int/foodsafety/consumer/3_fives_Beijing/en/index.html|work=World Health Organization|accessdate=3 June 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110609134315/http://www.who.int/foodsafety/consumer/3_fives_Beijing/en/index.html|archivedate=9 June 2011|df=}}</ref>
Before The 3 Fives, the WHO used the CINDI dietary guide, which included the CINDI pyramid. The guide was intended to help European health professionals and policymakers develop their own national nutrition guides. The pyramid has a large green base representing approximately two-thirds of the triangle's area, which is filled with vegetables, fruits, grains and starches. A middle layer shaded orange for "caution" is divided into two equal sections: low-fat milk and dairy; and beans, lentils, legumes, fish, eggs, poultry and lean meat. At the top is a small "red zone" of fats and sweets.<ref>{{cite web|title=CINDI dietary guide|url=http://www.euro.who.int/__data/assets/pdf_file/0010/119926/E70041.pdf|work=WHO Regional Office for Europe}}</ref>
===Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO)=== FAO provides technical assistance to countries for developing, revising and implementing food-based dietary guidelines (FBDG) and food guides in line with current scientific evidence. FAO also carries out periodic reviews on progress made in the development and use of dietary guidelines. FAO's food based dietary guidelines website collects more than 80 national guidelines.<ref>{{cite web|title=Food-based dietary guidelines|url=http://www.fao.org/nutrition/education/food-dietary-guidelines/home/en/|work=Food and Agriculture Organization}}</ref>
==Other guides== *The [[American Diabetes Association]] uses the '''Create Your Plate''' system, which divides a plate into three sections: non-starchy vegetables (the largest section), starchy foods, and meat or meat substitutes. Like [[MyPlate]], the ADA complements its plate with a glass of low-fat or nonfat milk.<ref>{{cite web|title=Create Your Plate|url=http://www.diabetes.org/food-and-fitness/food/planning-meals/create-your-plate/|work=American Diabetes Association|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> *The [[Germany|German]] Nutrition Society ({{lang-de|[[:de:Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ernährung|Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ernährung]]}}) publishes the '''Food Circle''' ({{lang-de|Ernährungskreis}}), which is divided into 30 percent cereals and potatoes; 26 percent vegetables and salad; 17 percent fruit; 18 percent milk and dairy; 7 percent meat, sausage, fish and eggs; and 2 percent fats and oils. Beverages, represented by a glass of water, are placed in the interior of the circle.<ref>{{cite web|title=Eine runde Sache: Der neue DGE-Ernährungskreis|url=http://www.dge.de/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=219|work=Deutsche Gesellschaft für Ernährung|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=German}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Der neue DGE-Ernährungskreis|url=http://www.dge.de/modules.php?name=News&file=article&sid=413|work=Der neue DGE-Ernährungskreis|accessdate=11 June 2011|language=German|date=1 April 2004}}</ref> *The [[Harvard School of Public Health]] uses the '''[[Healthy eating pyramid|Healthy Eating Pyramid]]''', which is split into nine sections, including a base of daily exercise and weight control. Compared to MyPlate, grains become whole grains, with refined grains in a "use sparingly" category; protein is split between "fish, poultry and [[egg (food)|eggs]]" and "[[nut (fruit)|nuts]], [[Seed#Edible seeds|seeds]], [[bean]]s and [[tofu]]" with [[red meat]] and processed meat in a "use sparingly" category; healthy fats and oils have their own section; and dairy can be substituted with calcium and vitamin D [[dietary supplement|supplements]]. To the side of the pyramid are [[alcoholic beverage|alcohol]] in moderation and a daily [[multivitamin]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Healthy Eating Pyramid|url=http://www.hsph.harvard.edu/nutritionsource/what-should-you-eat/pyramid/|work=University of Michigan Health System|publisher=Harvard University|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> *The [[Massachusetts]] Department of Health and Human Services uses the '''Plate Method''', which shows a plate that is one-half fruits and vegetables, one-quarter grains and starches, and one-quarter meat and protein.<ref>{{cite web|title=Use the Plate Method|url=http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=eohhs2terminal&L=5&L0=Home&L1=Consumer&L2=Prevention+and+Wellness&L3=Healthy+Living&L4=Eat+Better&sid=Eeohhs2&b=terminalcontent&f=dph_mass_in_motion_eat_better_plate_method&csid=Eeohhs2|work=Massachusetts Health and Human Services|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> *[[Overall Nutritional Quality Index]] *The [[Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine]] uses the '''Power Plate''', which promotes a [[vegan]] diet and is divided into equal parts fruit, grains, [[legume]]s and vegetables.<ref>{{cite web|title=Power Plate|url=http://www.pcrm.org/health/powerplate/|work=Physicians Committee for Responsible Medicine|accessdate=3 June 2011}}</ref> *The [[University of Michigan]] Health System uses the '''Healing Foods Pyramid''', which consists of 11 sections, including a base of [[drinking water|water]]. Compared to MyPlate, it adds sections for legumes, [[seasoning]]s, healthy fats, and eggs. Lean meats are in a weekly category, as are fish and [[seafood]]. An optional category includes alcohol, [[tea]] and [[Types of chocolate#Classification|dark chocolate]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Healing Foods Pyramid 2010|url=http://www.med.umich.edu/umim/food-pyramid|work=University of Michigan|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605000847/http://www.med.umich.edu/umim/food-pyramid/|archivedate=2011-06-05|df=}}</ref> *The [LiveWell for LIFE] project uses '''National Plates''' to show the ideal composition of diets in various EU countries that are both healthy, environmentally sustainable and affordable. This concept was pioneered by WWF in the UK and is now financially supported by the European Commission under the LIFE Plus programme(see [[Sustainable diet]]).<ref>{{cite web|title=LiveWell Plate|url=http://www.livewellforlife.eu/|work=LiveWell for LIFE}}</ref>
