{{Governance}}The concepts of '''security sector governance and reform''' ('''SSG/R''', or '''SSG''' and '''SSR''') generally refer to a process in [[Western world|Western]]-based [[international development]] and [[democratization]] to amend the [[national security|security sector]] of a state towards [[good governance]] and its principles, such as [[freedom of information]] and the [[rule of law]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_1_Security_Sector_Governance_EN.pdf|title=Security Sector Governance: Applying the principles of good governance to the security sector|last=|first=|publisher=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|year=2015|isbn=|series=SSR Backgrounder Series|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915023424/http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_1_Security_Sector_Governance_EN.pdf|archivedate=2017-09-15|df=}}{{Cite book|title=Security System Reform and Governance|last=|first=|publisher=OECD DAC|year=2005|isbn=92-64-00786-5|series=DAC Guidelines and Reference Series|location=Paris|pages=}} The objective of security sector reform (SSR) is to achieve good security sector governance (SSG)—where security actors are effective and accountable to their people. For example, SSR might guide decision-making on what form should the oversight of armed forces take or how transparent will intelligence agencies be according to legislation.{{Cite book|url=https://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S/RES/2151(2014)|title=UN Security Council Resolution 2151 (S/RES/2151) on Security sector reform: challenges and opportunities|last=|first=|publisher=United Nations|year=2014|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171121073122/http://www.un.org/en/ga/search/view_doc.asp?symbol=S%2FRES%2F2151%282014%29|archivedate=2017-11-21|df=}} Different nomenclature of the same overall framework include '''security system reform''' ('''SSR'''), '''security sector reconstruction''' ('''SSR''') and '''justice and security sector reform''' ('''JSSR''').{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_2_Security%20Sector%20Reform.pdf|title=Security Sector Reform: Applying the principles of good governance to the security sector|last=|first=|publisher=DCAF|year=2015|isbn=|series=SSR Backgrounder Series|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170913183845/http://www.dcaf.ch/sites/default/files/publications/documents/DCAF_BG_2_Security%20Sector%20Reform.pdf|archivedate=2017-09-13|df=}} == History == In 1994, the [[Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe]] (OSCE) adopted a Code of Conduct on Politico-Military Aspects of Security stating that the democratic control of the security sector as essential to stability.{{Cite book|url=http://www.osce.org/fsc/41355?download=true|title=Code of Conduct on Politico-Military Aspects of Security|last=|first=|publisher=OSCE|year=1994|isbn=|location=Vienna|pages=3|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170829145812/http://www.osce.org/fsc/41355?download=true|archivedate=2017-08-29|df=}} A framework for security sector reform (SSR) emerged in 1999 after [[international development]] actors observed from examples in [[South Africa]], [[Indonesia]] and countries in Eastern Europe that national security and its components were considered crucial in a state recovering from [[War|conflict]] or an [[Authoritarianism|authoritarian regime]]. Reportedly, the increasing number of [[Civil war|civil wars]] led development actors to look at the problem of insecurity from the perspective of good governance. The conclusion was that the security sector should adhere to the same rules of good governance as any other public service to curb conflict and violence.{{Cite news|url=https://www.clingendael.nl/publication/ssr-securing-its-success-justifying-its-relevance|title=SSR: Securing its success, justifying its relevance|last=Price|first=Megan|date=2014-08-19|work=Clingendael|access-date=|last2=van Veen|first2=Erwin|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826234737/https://www.clingendael.nl/publication/ssr-securing-its-success-justifying-its-relevance|archivedate=2017-08-26|df=}} In 2014, the [[United Nations Security Council]] (UNSC) adopted its first stand-alone resolution on SSR and within it the role of security sector reform in stabilizing post-conflict countries.{{Cite web|url=https://www.un.org/press/en/2014/sc11369.doc.htm|title=Unanimously Adopting Resolution 2151 (2014), Security Council Underscores Need for National Ownership of Security-Sector Reform|last=|first=|date=2014-04-28|website=www.un.org|language=en|access-date=2017-08-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170820151018/http://www.un.org/press/en/2014/sc11369.doc.htm|archivedate=2017-08-20|df=}}{{Cite web|url=http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/articles/2015/02/13/undp-sees-security-sector-reform-as-foundation-for-peace-and-development-.html|title=UNDP sees Security Sector Reform as foundation for Peace and Development|last=|first=|date=2015-02-13|website=UNDP|language=en|access-date=2017-08-25|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170826000511/http://www.undp.org/content/undp/en/home/presscenter/articles/2015/02/13/undp-sees-security-sector-reform-as-foundation-for-peace-and-development-.html|archivedate=2017-08-26|df=}} == Scope == [[File:Female police officer of Denmark.jpg|thumb|The [[Service quality|quality of the service]] provided by the police, such as the pictured [[Police of Denmark]], is a component of security sector governance and reform]]There is no single globally accepted definition of security sector reform (SSR), but it generally refers to a process to reform or rebuild a state's [[National security|security sector]] towards good security sector governance (SSG).{{Cite book|url=https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/sites/devco/files/joint-communication-ssr-20160705-p1-854572_en.pdf|title=Elements for an EU-wide strategic framework to support security sector reform, JOIN(2016) 31 final|last=|first=|publisher=European Commission|year=2016|isbn=|location=Strasbourg|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825234526/https://ec.europa.eu/europeaid/sites/devco/files/joint-communication-ssr-20160705-p1-854572_en.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/115810.pdf|title=Security Sector Reform|last=|first=|publisher=USAID, US Departments of Defense and State|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107024030/https://www.state.gov/documents/organization/115810.pdf|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} Good SSG is usually defined as a number of idealized principles and good practices of a healthy security sector servicing its people. Likewise, the objective of SSR is defined as the application of the same principles of [[good governance]] to the security sector as to any other public sector service delivery, such as [[public health]] or [[education]].{{Cite web|url=http://dcaf.ch/about-ssgr|title=About SSG/R|last=|first=|date=|website=DCAF (Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces)|language=en|access-date=2017-11-04|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107012716/http://dcaf.ch/about-ssgr|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} For example, the [[Development Assistance Committee]] (DAC) of the [[OECD|Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (]]OECD) has defined four standards that SSR should strive for:
1. Establishment of effective governance, oversight and accountability in the security system; 2) improved delivery of security and justice services; 3) development of local leadership and ownership of the reform process; and 4) sustainability of justice and security service delivery.
The target of SSR are the components of the state that uphold [[national security]]. Although the security sector is therefore a wide term open to interpretation, it is generally used to describe the structures, institutions and personnel responsible for the management, provision and oversight of security in a certain country.{{Cite book|url=https://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/publications/ssr/ssr_perspective_2012.pdf|title=The United Nations SSR Perspective|last=|first=|publisher=UN SSR Unit|year=2012|isbn=|location=New York|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170519215426/http://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/publications/ssr/ssr_perspective_2012.pdf|archivedate=2017-05-19|df=}} Therefore, the scope and target of SSR has usually been defined comprising the following four groups: * Core security actors, such as armed forces, police, gendarmerie, border guards, customs and immigration, and intelligence and security services; * security management and oversight bodies, such as ministries of defence and internal affairs, financial management bodies and public complaints commissions; * justice and law enforcement institutions, such as the judiciary, prisons, prosecution services, traditional justice systems; and * non-statutory security forces, such as private security companies, guerrilla armies and private militia.{{Cite book|url=https://www.eda.admin.ch/content/dam/deza/en/documents/themen/fragile-kontexte/224402-oecd-handbook-security-system-reform_EN.pdf|title=The OECD DAC Handbook on Security System Reform (SSR) - Supporting Security and Justice|last=|first=|publisher=OECD DAC|year=2007|isbn=|location=Paris|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170821172956/https://www.eda.admin.ch/content/dam/deza/en/documents/themen/fragile-kontexte/224402-oecd-handbook-security-system-reform_EN.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-21|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.unog.ch/80256EDD006B8954/%28httpAssets%29/904B9EE812B7591FC12573F400322816/$file/Joint+Seminar_A-62-659_S-2008-39.pdf|title=Securing peace and development: the role of the United Nations in supporting security sector reform - Report of the Secretary-General (A/62/659)|last=|first=|publisher=United Nations|year=2008|isbn=|location=New York|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140905032133/http://www.unog.ch/80256EDD006B8954/(httpAssets)/904B9EE812B7591FC12573F400322816/$file/Joint+Seminar_A-62-659_S-2008-39.pdf|archivedate=2014-09-05|df=}}{{Cite news|url=https://fba.se/en/how-we-work/security-sector-reform/|title=Security Sector Reform|last=|first=|date=|work=Folke Bernadotte Academy|access-date=2017-08-23|language=en|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160826130304/https://fba.se/en/how-we-work/security-sector-reform/|archivedate=2016-08-26|df=}} == Objective == [[File:SSG and SSR.png|thumb|A diagram of the relationship between security sector reform and governance relative to time and quality|left]]To observe and measure the quality of SSG as well as set more definite objectives, [[international development]] actors generally break down good security sector governance into different principless that are believed to showcase different subparts of a healthy security sector under democratic control.{{Cite web|url=http://www.unescap.org/resources/what-good-governance|title=What is Good Governance?|last=|first=|date=2009-06-10|website=United Nations ESCAP|language=en|access-date=2017-04-09|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170423153306/http://www.unescap.org/resources/what-good-governance|archivedate=2017-04-23|df=}} While exact configurations vary, some of the most common principles or objectives of good SSG that are commonly used include [[accountability]], [[rule of law]], and [[effectiveness]].{{Cite book|url=http://www.osce.org/secretariat/231176|title=Security Sector Governance and Reform: Guidelines for OSCE Staff|last=|first=|publisher=Organization for Security and Co-operation in Europe (OSCE)|year=2016|isbn=|location=Vienna|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825185357/http://www.osce.org/secretariat/231176|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}}{{Cite journal|last=Weiss|first=Thomas G.|date=2000-10-01|title=Governance, good governance and global governance: Conceptual and actual challenges|url=https://dx.doi.org/10.1080/713701075|journal=Third World Quarterly|volume=21|issue=5|pages=795–814|doi=10.1080/713701075|issn=0143-6597}} A multitude of different practical situations of good SSG exist according to development actors: For example, in a security sector lead by good governance, the [[use of force]] is defined by a legal framework. This subsequently requires, among others, that publicly transparent [[law]]s are in place; oversight and [[separation of powers]] mechanisms are established and working; and the state's [[Legitimacy (political)|legitimate]] use of force is regulated through strategies and policies. An operational level example would be improved and open interaction between the public and the security sector, including functioning [[freedom of information]] and [[complaint]] institutes. SSR is aimed at the existence of both national security and [[human security]]. However, the goals of providing national and human security can be conflictual in the context of conflict-torn societies which lack the framework of democratic governance. According to Florian Weigand, the experiences of SSR in [[Afghanistan]], for example, have prompted a debate on the advantages of providing human rather than state security in the process of state-building.{{Cite book|url=http://www.lse.ac.uk/internationalDevelopment/pdf/WP/WP135.pdf|title=How can security sector reforms contribute to State-Building? The case of the Afghan Police Reform|last=Weigand|first=Florian|publisher=London School of Economics and Political Science|year=2013|isbn=|location=London|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170809085941/http://www.lse.ac.uk/internationaldevelopment/pdf/wp/wp135.pdf|archivedate=2017-08-09|df=}} ==Implementation== [[File:MONUSCO SSR.jpg|thumb|The [[United Nations|UN]] peacekeeping operation in the [[Democratic Republic of the Congo]] ([[MONUSCO]]) providing security sector reform assistance]]SSR is considered an instrument of international [[development aid]]; and attaining good SSG is seen by practitioners as a conflict prevention tool and as a post-conflict stabilizer.{{Cite web|url=http://www.isf2016.ch/Programme/Summaries/1.3.-Security-Sector-Governance-in-West-Africa-Regional-norms-Local-experiences|title=Security Sector Governance in West Africa: Regional norms, local experiences|last=International Security Forum 2016|first=|date=2016-06-13|website=www.isf2016.ch|language=en-GB|access-date=2017-05-29|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170825190641/http://www.isf2016.ch/Programme/Summaries/1.3.-Security-Sector-Governance-in-West-Africa-Regional-norms-Local-experiences|archivedate=2017-08-25|df=}} Examples of mechanisms that international actors reportedly use to perform security sector reform include [[disarmament, demobilization and reintegration]] (DDR) programmes to try and synchronize reforms to the security sector—and rule of law reforms as justice and security sectors are often considered intertwined.{{Cite book|url=http://www.unddr.org/uploads/documents/IDDRS%206.10%20DDR%20and%20SSR.pdf|title=Integrated Disarmament, Demobilization and Reintegration Standards|last=|first=|publisher=UN DDR Resource Centre|year=2009|isbn=|location=|pages=|chapter=6.10 DDR and Security Sector Reform|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151123003322/http://www.unddr.org/uploads/documents/IDDRS%206.10%20DDR%20and%20SSR.pdf|archivedate=2015-11-23|df=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.ictj.org/sites/default/files/ICTJ-DDR-SSR-ResearchBrief-2010-English.pdf|title=Transitional Justice, DDR, and Security Sector Reform|last=Cutter Patel|first=Ana|publisher=International Center for Transitional Justice|year=2010|isbn=|location=|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171107002910/https://www.ictj.org/sites/default/files/ICTJ-DDR-SSR-ResearchBrief-2010-English.pdf|archivedate=2017-11-07|df=}} Likewise, SSR can be performed along transitional justice processes if the security sector has a legacy of violence against the population—and during [[security policy]] discussions to use SSR in supporting the implementation and reviews of the states' national security policy and strategy. SSR is not understood by researchers to be limited to a single political situation, but rather can be introduced in various contexts. The circumstances under which reform efforts are undertaken are often classified as three different reform environments: post-conflict, [[Provisional government|transitional]] and [[Developed country|developed countries]]. Nevertheless, security sector reform is most commonly introduced in post-conflict settings after [[war]] has ceased.{{Cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/security-governance-post-conflict-peacebuilding|title=Security Governance in Post-Conflict Peacebuilding|last=Bryden|first=Alan|last2=Hänggi|first2=Heiner|publisher=Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)|year=2005|isbn=978-3-8258-9019-3|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170915024200/http://www.dcaf.ch/security-governance-post-conflict-peacebuilding|archivedate=2017-09-15|df=}} However, its insensitive application to such contexts has raised criticism. For example, Jane Chanaa has argued that there is a concept–context divide because conceptualisation overshadowed the understanding on how the idea adapts to the local situations whereas Safal Ghimire has noted that such a chasm exists also because the 'SSR' concept does not talk about reforms in the benefactors.{{Cite book|title=Chanaa, Jane. "Adelphi Paper 344: Security Sector Reform: Issues, Challenges and Prospects." (2002).|last=Chanaa|first=Jane|publisher=Oxford University Press for the International Institute for Strategic Studies|year=2002|isbn=9780198516743|location=New York|pages=}}{{Cite journal|last=Ghimire|first=Safal|date=March 2016|title=Making security sector reform organic: infrastructures for peace as an entry point?|url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/21647259.2016.1156813?journalCode=rpcb20|journal=Peacebuilding|volume=4|pages=|doi=|via=Taylor & Francis Online}} == See also == {{div col|colwidth=}} * [[Gender and security sector reform]] * [[Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces|Geneva Centre for the Democratic Control of Armed Forces (DCAF)]] * [[International relations]] * [[International security]] * [[Peacebuilding]] * [[Public finance]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==Further reading== ;Books * {{cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/Publications/Gender-Security-Sector-Reform-Toolkit|title=Gender and Security Sector Reform Toolkit|last1=Bastick|first1=M.|last2=Valasek|first2=K.|publisher=DCAF|year=2008|isbn=978-92-9222-074-7|location=Geneva|pages=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130602182103/http://www.dcaf.ch/Publications/Gender-Security-Sector-Reform-Toolkit|archivedate=2013-06-02|df=}} * {{cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/Publications/Reform-and-Reconstruction-of-the-Security-Sector|title=Reform and Reconstruction of the Security Sector|last1=Hänggi|first1=H.|last2=Bryden|first2=A.|publisher=DCAF|year=2004|isbn=3-8258-7770-1|location=Geneva|pages=}} * {{cite book|url=http://www.dcaf.ch/Publications/Security-Governance-in-Post-Conflict-Peacebuilding|title=Security Governance in Post-Conflict Peacebuilding|last1=Hänggi|first1=H.|last2=Bryden|first2=A.|publisher=DCAF|year=2005|isbn=978-3-8258-9019-3|location=Geneva|pages=}} * {{cite book|url=http://www.ciaonet.org/wps/laa03/laa03.pdf|title=Providing Security for the People: Security Sector Reform in Africa|last1=Lalá|first1=A.|last2=Fitz-Gerald|first2=A.|publisher=GFN-SSR|year=2003|isbn=0-9546500-0-X|location=Shrivenham, UK|pages=}} * {{cite book |last1=Scnabel|first1=A. | first2=H. | last2=Ehrhardt| year=2006 | title=Security Sector Reform and Post-Conflict Peacebuilding |url=http://i.unu.edu/unu/u/publication/000/002/361/securitysectorreform.pdf |isbn=92-808-1109-6 |publisher=United Nations University Press|location=Tokyo|pages=}} '''Articles, papers and guidelines''' * {{cite book|url=https://www.files.ethz.ch/isn/100035/op_2008_2.pdf|title=Security Sector {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2013}} {{Use British English|date=October 2013}} [[File:The Frythe, Welwyn (without border).png|thumb|The Frythe|350px]] '''The Frythe''' is a [[country house]] set in its own grounds in rural [[Hertfordshire]], just south of the village of [[Welwyn]], about 30 miles north of [[London]].
==History== ===Early history=== The Frythe was part of the property of [[Holywell Priory, Shoreditch]], and in 1523 William Wilshere obtained a sixty-year lease of the Frythe from the priory. As a result of the [[dissolution of the monasteries]], in 1539 the property was granted to Sir [[John Gostwick]] and Joan his wife. Within ten years, Wilshere had purchased The Frythe from Gostwick's heirs, and the property remained in the possession of the Wilshere family for several centuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=43597 |title=''Parishes: Welwyn'', A History of the County of Hertford|volume=3 |year=1912|page=165-171|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref>
The present "Gothic revival" mansion was built in 1846 for [[William Wilshere]] (MP for [[Great Yarmouth (UK Parliament constituency)|Great Yarmouth]] from 1837 to 1846). The architects were Thomas Smith and [[Edward Blore]]. After William Wilshere's death in 1867 the house was enlarged by his brother Charles Willes Wilshere who inherited it. In 1908 on Charles Wilshere's death, it passed on to his three unmarried daughters until the last one died in 1934. The estate passed to a great-nephew, Captain Gerald Maunsell Gamul Farmer who ran the house as "The Frythe Residential and Private Hotel".<ref name=knaggs>{{cite web|url=http://www.jefferyknaggs.webspace.virginmedia.com/Frythe.html|title=The Frythe, Welwyn, Hertfordshire|accessdate=6 January 2018|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150313105638/http://www.jefferyknaggs.webspace.virginmedia.com/Frythe.html|archivedate=13 March 2015|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
===SOE Station X=== [[File:Service of of Major John Brown in Special Operations Executive (soe) at Sta Ix, the Frythe, Welwyn Garden City in the Second World War HU56777.jpg|thumb|right|160px|Weapon developed by Station X]] 'The Frythe' was commandeered in August 1939 by the British [[Military Intelligence]].<ref name="Timelapse">{{cite web|url=http://www.timelapse.dk/soe.php|title=S.O.E.|accessdate=2009-04-25}}</ref> During the [[World War II|Second World War]] it became a secret British [[Special Operations Executive]] factory known as [[Station IX]] making commando equipment. Secret research included military vehicles and equipment, explosives and technical sabotage, [[camouflage]], [[Biological warfare|biological]] and [[chemical warfare]]. In the grounds of The Frythe small cabins and barracks functioned as laboratories and workshops.<ref name="Timelapse"/>
===Research facility=== The Frythe was for many years a commercial research facility, operated by [[Imperial Chemical Industries|ICI]] from 1946, by [[Unilever]] from 1963 and by [[Smith, Kline & French]] from 1977.<ref name=knaggs/>
====Unilever==== From 1946 to 1963 the site was shared by [[Imperial Chemical Industries|ICI]] with [[Unilever]].<ref name=knaggs/> New buildings were built by Unilever in the 1960s, with a contract for £400,000 in 1964 to [[Taylor Woodrow]]. Research was conducted on edible oils, margarine, ice cream, and frozen foods in the 1960s. Techniques included [[molecular biophysics]], [[X-ray crystallography]], [[nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy]] (NMR), [[mass spectrometry]], ESR spectroscopy ([[electron paramagnetic resonance]]), and [[infrared spectroscopy]].<ref name=knaggs/>
====GSK==== [[File:Cimetidine-xtal-3D-balls.png|thumb|right|Cimetidine, discovered at The Frythe]] [[Smith, Kline & French]] discovered Tagamet ([[Cimetidine]]) at The Frythe in 1971, which treats [[Peptic ulcer disease|peptic ulcers]] by Sir [[James Black (pharmacologist)|James Black]] FRS and [[C. Robin Ganellin]] FRS with research on [[H2 antagonist]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=Qw4lBQAAQBAJ&pg=PR8&lpg=PR8&dq=%22Robin+Ganellin%22+Frythe&source=bl&ots=8q6cDtybcR&sig=BwhQA5_WTm1Wuy-3PpxDSzIAD0g&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiwhpXms8PYAhXoAsAKHQ24AOAQ6AEISjAI#v=onepage&q=%22Robin%20Ganellin%22%20Frythe&f=false|title=Pharmacology of Histamine Receptors |first1= C. R. |last1=Ganellin|first2=M. E. |last2=Parsons|publisher=Butterworth-Heinemann|year=1982|isbn=978-0-7236-0589-8}}</ref>
===Residential Accommodation=== The Frythe site was closed by [[GlaxoSmithKline]] and sold to a property development company on 19 December 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whtimes.co.uk/news/welwyn-site-sold-for-15m-1-745168|title=Welwyn site sold for £15m|date=3 December 2010|publisher=Welwyn Hatfield Times|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref> The conversion of the property into flats was completed in spring 2017.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.whtimes.co.uk/news/new-era-for-welwyn-s-former-commando-gadget-lab-1-4976306|title=New era for Welwyn’s former Commando gadget lab|date=16 April 2017|publisher=Welwyn Hatfield Times|accessdate=6 January 2018}}</ref>

{{merge to|Perennial philosophy|date=November 2018}} '''The Primordial Tradition''' is a school of religious philosophy which holds its origins in the [[philosophia perennis]], or [[perennial philosophy]], which is in turn a development of the [[prisca theologia]] of the Middle Ages.<ref>Antoine Faivre and Karen-Claire Voss, Western Esotericism and the Science of Religions, in Numen, Vol. 42 (E. J. Brill, Leiden 1995) 50-51</ref>
The Primordial Tradition seeks to establish a fundamental origin of religious belief in all authentic religious teachings, adhering to the principle that universal truths are a cross cultural phenomenon and transcendent of their respective traditions, mythologies, and religious beliefs. The idea of the Primordial Tradition was well received by both practitioners and the academic community, and its development was actively endorsed by the International Conference of Religions in Chicago, 1893<ref>Antoine Faivre and Karen-Claire Voss, Western Esotericism and the Science of Religions, in Numen, Vol. 42 (E. J. Brill, Leiden 1995) 56</ref>
The Primordial Tradition does not elevate any tradition or religion above another and instead upholds the truth claims of all authentic religions and spiritual movements. Adherents of the Primordial Tradition can be found in any religious system such as [[Hinduism]], [[Buddhism]], [[Paganism]], [[Christianity]] or [[Islam]].
By examining the foundations of religious thought as philosophical [[truth value]]s, the Primordial Tradition seeks to produce a level of wisdom or gnosis which is greater than that which would be provided by the study of a single religious system. The process utilized is similar to the study of the [[history of religions]] and [[comparative mythology]] as is found in the works of authors such as [[Mircea Eliade]]. It can also be found in the school of archetypal psychology and in the ideas of [[Carl Jung]]
Key proponents of the Primordial Tradition have included [[Rene Guenon]], [[Frithjof Schuon]], [[Julius Evola]], [[Harvey Spencer Lewis]], [[Ananda Coomaraswamy]], [[Elémire Zolla]], [[Alain Danielou]], [[Jean-Louis Michon]], [[Gottfried Leibniz]], [[Aldous Huxley]], and [[Plato]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2015}}
The [[Traditionalist School]] bases its teachings on religious belief on the concept of a pre-existent primordial tradition found in different religions.<ref>''The Unanimous Tradition, Essays on the essential unity of all religions'', by Joseph Epes Brown, Titus Burckhardt, Rama P. Coomaraswamy, Gai Eaton, Isaline B. Horner, Toshihiko Izutsu, Martin Lings, Seyyed Hossein Nasr, Lord Northbourne, Marco Pallis, Whitall N. Perry, Leo Schaya, Frithjof Schuon, Philip Sherrard, William Stoddart, Elémire Zolla, edited by Ranjit Fernando, Sri Lanka Institute of Traditional Studies, 1991 {{ISBN|955-9028-01-4}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.primordialtraditions.com Primordial Traditions Journal]

'''Toxic alcohols''' are a group of [[alcohol]]s that include [[methanol]], [[ethylene glycol]], [[propylene glycol]], and [[isopropyl alcohol]].<ref name=EM2016>{{cite journal|last1=Beauchamp|first1=GA|last2=Valento|first2=M|title=Toxic Alcohol Ingestion: Prompt Recognition And Management In The Emergency Department.|journal=Emergency medicine practice|date=September 2016|volume=18|issue=9|pages=1–20|pmid=27538060}}</ref> They are alcohols that should not be drunk.<ref name=EM2016/> They are in contrast to [[ethanol]], which is commonly [[alcohol (drug)|used as a recreational drug]] and is the alcohol that is found in [[alcoholic drink]]s.

In [[actor-network theory]] (ANT), '''translation''' is the process that allows a network to be represented by a single entity, which can in itself be an individual or another network.<ref>Callon, M. & Latour, B., 1981. [http://www.bruno-latour.fr/sites/default/files/09-LEVIATHAN-GB.pdf "Unscrewing the big Leviathan: how actors macro-structure reality and how sociologists help them to do so"]. In K. Knorr-Cetina & A. V. Cicourel, eds. Advances in social theory and methodology: Towards an integration of micro- and macro-sociologies. Boston: Routledge & Kegan Paul, pp. 277-303.</ref>
In 1986, [[Michel Callon]] published the seminal article [http://www.vub.ac.be/SOCO/tesa/RENCOM/Callon%20%281986%29%20Some%20elements%20of%20a%20sociology%20of%20translation.pdf "Some elements of a sociology of translation"],<ref>Callon, M., 1986. [http://www.homepages.ucl.ac.uk/~ucessjb/S3%20Reading/callon%201986.pdf "The sociology of an actor-network"]. In M. Callon, J. Law, & A. Rip, eds. Mapping the Dynamics of Science and Technology. London: Macmillan, p. 19–34.</ref> in which he summarized the process of translation as four 'moments' or phases:
# [[Problematization]] - the definition of the nature of the problem in a specific situation by an actor (a group or an individual) and the consequential establishment of dependency # [[Interessement]] - "locking" other actors into the roles that were proposed for them in the actor's <!--approach/-->programme for resolving that problem # [[Enrolment (sociology)|Enrolment]] - the definition and interrelation of the roles that were allocated to other actors in the previous step # [[Mobilization (translation)|Mobilization]] - ensuring that supposed spokespersons for relevant collective entities are properly representative of all members of the network that are acting as a single agent.

{{Unreferenced|date=June 2007}} :''For the [[Pitchshifter (band)|Pitchshifter]] song, see [[Underachiever (song)]]. For the hip hop duo, see [[The Underachievers]].''
An '''underachiever''' is a person who fails to achieve his or her [[potential]] or does not do as well as expected.{{by whom?|date=November 2012}}
Of particular interest is '''academic underachievement'''. Studies of individuals who have not realized their apparent potential have identified [[Learning disability|learning disabilities]], [[Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder|ADHD]], and many other educational problems, and subsequently enabled methods of addressing these problems. Current theories among academic scholars prefer to address underperformance problems with remedial help.
The term is also used more generally; for example, a sports team that contains many star players but still loses games against teams with relatively little obvious talent might be termed underachieving. A [[stock]] which achieves poor [[Profit (accounting)|profit]] and/or [[capital gain]]s despite sound underlying business and/or [[asset]]s may be called underachieving.

'''Velleity''' is the lowest degree of volition, a slight wish or tendency.<ref>{{cite web|title=Velleity|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/velleity|accessdate=4 May 2014}}</ref>
==Examples of usage==
The [[marketer]] Matt Bailey described it as "a desire to see something done, but not enough desire to make it happen".<ref name=Bailey>Matt Bailey, "Viral marketing", excerpt "Analytics 1.0 - A Case of Velleity," found at [http://www.sitelogicmarketing.com/blog/07-analytics-velleity Site Logic marketing website]. Accessed April 29, 2009.</ref>
===In modern writing===
Matt Bailey expressed an attempt "to bring it back, as it has more relevance now than ever."<ref name=Bailey /> He writes that: {{quote|Velleity is what keeps companies locked in this mindset of reporting useless numbers. Desiring, even expecting to someday have an epiphany of change, but not willing to change the mindset or the culture of locked-in reporting to achieve it. Nor are they willing to ask the hard questions in order to uncover what must be done.|Matt Bailey, marketing writer<ref name=Bailey />}}
===In philosophy===
[[Friedrich Nietzsche]] describes the velleity of an [[artist]] as a "desire to ''be'' 'what he is able to represent, conceive, and express'...."<ref> Aaron Ridley, in "Nietzsche, philosophy and the arts," ed. by Salim Kemal, Ivan Gaskell, Daniel W. Conway, at pp. 128-131 (Cambridge University Press, 2002) {{ISBN|0-521-52272-2}}, {{ISBN|978-0-521-52272-4}} (emphasis provided), found at [https://books.google.com/books?id=8GzFg3pH4SIC&pg=PA130&lpg=PA130&dq=Velleity+%2B+philosophy&source=bl&ots=MljPsygceA&sig=SWt2zXpiLVhU9oBymK3jfNIAKQs&hl=en&ei=TrH4SfCODNOGmQeOj-GYDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=7#PPA134,M1 Google Book search]. Accessed April 29, 2009. </ref> Nietzsche championed the [[will to power]], which can be encapsulated{{by whom?|date=November 2012}} as starting with velleity, in his [[free-will theorem]].
Keith David Wyma refers frequently to the "concept of velleity", citing [[Thomas Aquinas]] as a pioneer of introducing the idea into philosophy.<ref name=Wyma> Keith David Wyma, ''Crucible of reason'', pp. 197, 221, 223, 225, 227 (Rowman and Littlefield 2004). {{ISBN|978-0-7425-3538-1}}. Found at [https://books.google.com/books?id=wOVY0Y18rXIC&pg=PA197&lpg=PA197&dq=velleity+%2B+concept&source=bl&ots=pkCbLYRXbs&sig=ZLna9O88cXutB1Ov2vJJ0lB6SVo&hl=en&ei=iggITMmWMoH7lweW9uGyDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=9&ved=0CCwQ6AEwCA#v=onepage&q=velleity%20%20%20concept&f=false Google books]. Accessed June 3, 2010. </ref>
===In psychology=== {{Main|Volition (psychology)}} Psychologist Avi Sion writes, "''Many psychological concepts may only be defined and explained with reference to velleity''." (''Emphasis in original''.)<ref name=Sion>Avi Sion, "Volition and allied causal concepts," p. 190 (2004). {{ISBN|978-2-9700091-6-0}}. Found at [https://books.google.com/books?id=eYiCeazY2-kC&pg=PA190&lpg=PA190&dq=velleity+%2B+concept&source=bl&ots=l8Zm1Mjzo1&sig=00oJtvRAUTTKMkyZwtOjVSWfXO8&hl=en&ei=iggITMmWMoH7lweW9uGyDg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CBUQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=velleity%20%2B%20concept&f=false Google books]. Also found at [http://www.thelogician.net/4b_volition/4b_chapter_09.htm The Logician website]. All accessed June 3, 2010.</ref> An example he cites is that "an ordinarily desirable object can only properly be called 'interesting' or 'tempting' to that [[Agency (philosophy)|agent]] at that time, if he manifests some velleity...."<ref name=Sion /> He distinguishes between the two types of velleity - "''to do'' something and one ''not to do'' something...."<ref name=Sion /> Furthermore, he asserts, "The concept of velleity is also important because it enables us to understand the co-existence of conflicting values."<ref name=Sion /> A person could thus have "double velleity" or "a mix of velleity for something and a volition for its opposite: the latter dominates, of course, but that does not erase the fact of velleity."<ref name=Sion />
Kathy Kolbe also lists velleity as a "key concept of [[conation]]."<ref name=Kolbe>See [http://www.kolbe.com/knol/keyConceptsOfConation.htm Kathy Kolbe's website page on Conation]. Accessed June 3, 2010.</ref>
